Subject: Texts and Traditions

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The importance of sacred texts to the tradition
ExampleText: Explore how Paul of Tarsus expanded the Christian movement from Jerusalem to Rome and to the world. Place the writing of his letters into the context of this journey.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The importance of sacred texts to the tradition
ExampleText: After the death of Christ, the Christians were persecuted, and many died for their faith. Research the martyrdom of some of the early Christians. Investigate the texts which describe these stories.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The importance of sacred texts to the tradition
ExampleText: Consider the impact that Emperor's Constantine battle of the Milvian bridge had on the Christian movement. Explain what transpired and the result of the battle.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The importance of sacred texts to the tradition
ExampleText: Investigate which Gospels did not make it into the canon and comment on why the Catholic Church did not include them as part of the canon.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The importance of sacred texts to the tradition
ExampleText: Describe the process of canonisation in the Christian Bible.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The importance of sacred texts to the tradition
ExampleText: Explore the major moments of acceptance and / or rejection of particular texts into the Jewish Bible.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The importance of sacred texts to the tradition
ExampleText: Review controversies in the religious tradition over the acceptance of particular texts into the scriptures of the tradition.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The importance of sacred texts to the tradition
ExampleText: Trace the revelation of the texts of the Qur'an using maps and a timeline to place particular surahs in their historical context.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The importance of sacred texts to the tradition
ExampleText: Discuss: In the Christian tradition, what is meant by the terms deuterocanonical and apocryphal?

ExampleText: Creating a timeline of the development of the Christian Scriptures

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The importance of sacred texts to the tradition
ExampleText: Students should note that the Christian Bible is made up of two main sections, the Jewish Bible (sometimes called The Hebrew Scriptures or Old Testament) and the Christian Scriptures (often referred to as the New Testament.) These sections can be further divided into smaller sections (The Gospels, the Letters of Paul, etc.).

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The importance of sacred texts to the tradition
ExampleText: A quick search on the internet will show that there is no agreed dating to many of the writings in the Bible. However, this task asks students to explore the possibilities of dates of writing and the major moments of acceptance of texts. Explain to students that not all texts are easily dated - compare this to most websites on the internet which have no indication of the date, author or location. Scholars have to look at the content and the context of books to determine possible dates when they were written.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The importance of sacred texts to the tradition
ExampleText: Have students explore the dating of some of the major books in the Bible.

ExampleText: Examples of learning activities

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The exegesis of texts
ExampleText: Use a Kahoot to identify the literary forms and literary techniques in given extracts.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The exegesis of texts
ExampleText: Take a children's nursery rhyme or a song with cultural references and highlight particular words and phrases. Research possible meanings of those highlighted sections.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The exegesis of texts
ExampleText: Identify extracts containing various types of literary forms and techniques on the board, and as a class, identify the literary forms and techniques and the impact they have on the text.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The exegesis of texts
ExampleText: Annotate a passage and identify: context, background information, literary forms and techniques, themes and message to original audience.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The exegesis of texts
ExampleText: Identify allusions made to Old Testament biblical figures in the infancy narrative of the Gospel according to Luke and explain relevance and significance of the text on the intended audience. Comment on the connections the author wants the audience to make.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The exegesis of texts
ExampleText: Take a local newspaper and identify the variety of literary forms in the paper such as news stories, advertising, classifieds, obituaries, sports news, letters to the editor. Rank these types of literary forms according to the 'truthfulness' of the form. Explore the way different cultures might read parts of the newspaper differently.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The exegesis of texts
ExampleText: Explore the audience of a particular text and show how the text is written specifically for the needs and concerns of that audience at that time. This could take a variety of texts into account, from religious texts through to the school newsletter.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The exegesis of texts
ExampleText: Apply exegetical methods to a passage from the chosen religious text and identify literary context, background information, literary forms and techniques, themes, and the meaning for the original audience.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The exegesis of texts
ExampleText: Literary forms in our local texts

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The exegesis of texts
ExampleText: Using a local newspaper, identify and select a variety of articles: news stories, advertising, classifieds, obituaries, sports news, letters to the editor (these could be printed from an online version of the news but should include a wide range of journalistic forms).

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The exegesis of texts
ExampleText: Students place each piece of information into categories and name the categories. They may come up with labels such as 'News', 'Ads', 'Letters', etc. They then describe the criteria they used to decide which piece of information fits into which category - this may have to do with content, style, form or a mix of those areas.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The exegesis of texts
ExampleText: Students could then discuss levels or types of truth which are given in the various categories of 'news'. For example, a letter to the editor, which expresses an opinion, might be seen to have a different type of truth to a hard news article. Students may find some difficulty in deciding how true an advertisement is.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The exegesis of texts
ExampleText: Using one article, students could then consider what needs to be explained from that article to a reader from another country: people, locations, certain phrases might all make little sense to someone who isn't from the area where the newspaper was published. Students could highlight those words and write a brief explanation to allow the reader to come to a stronger understanding of the intent and content of the text

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: Outcome 3

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: Analyse a range of understandings and interpretations of sacred texts as understood or expressed by the later religious tradition.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: Examples of learning activities

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: Outline the key messages about the environment and Earth gained from a reading of Genesis 1 and 2. Explore how different ways of reading can come up with a variety of responses. Then, referencing the Encyclical, Laudato Si, explore Pope Francis's message concerning the environment, and examine his views about using an interpretation of Genesis that can impact on our response to the ecological issues facing the world.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: Investigate how the incarnation, crucifixion and resurrection has been portrayed and represented in artwork over the centuries. Explore how different cultures around the world have used artwork to guide their understanding of their religious tradition.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: Investigate how the image of Jesus has developed and evolved over time in artwork, sculpture and film. Comment on whether the changes reflect the historical, sociocultural and religious ideas of the time.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: In the Hebrew Scriptures, Messianic prophecies about the coming messiah were made by Prophets. Compare and contrast the messianic expectations of the Jewish people of First Century Palestine of the prophesised messiah, and discuss whether Jesus reflected their expectations. How did the Christian tradition interpret the Hebrew Scriptures to justify their understanding of Jesus?

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: Research a Jewish Passover festival meal as it is lived in the Jewish tradition today. Explain what each item on the plate represents in the Exodus narrative.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: Brainstorm songs that have been used to represent or portray a historical event in a religious tradition. For example, 'By the Rivers of Babylon' by Boney M. is a song capturing the feelings of the Israelites when exiled from their homeland by the Babylonians.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: Compare and contrast the two Infancy Narratives and investigate how they have been portrayed in the Western understanding of Christmas today.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: Using film as a medium for presenting interpretations of text and the issues arising from texts, explore how the original texts have been interpreted for a different cultural context.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: Explore how passages about a particular issue in Islamic life (such as marriage, money, treatment of others) have been used in another period of history.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: Referring to passages such as 2:62 and 2:136, explore how Islam expresses an understanding that Islam is a universal message addressed to all peoples of the world. Discuss: How might stories of Salman Al Farisi in the Hadith explain particular interpretations of these verses?

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: Explore themes in texts such as faith, prophecy, betrayal and sacrifice compared to how those themes have been interpreted in films

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: Divide the class into groups and allocate one theme to each group. Students research and locate examples of their theme in their sacred text and present their findings to the class.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: View a film such as The Chronicles of Narnia; The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe; TheNeverending Story or The Matrix and explain how the above themes are portrayed and represented in the film.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: Draw a Venn diagram and make connections and comparisons between the two texts.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: Describe how allusions, symbolism, imagery, colour have been used in the later tradition.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Sacred texts and later traditions
ExampleText: Analyse how the film draws inspiration from the sacred text in its portrayal of the later tradition.

ExampleText: Examples of learning activities

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: Compare and contrast the foundational story of the binding of Isaac (Genesis) and the binding of Ishmael (Qur'an). Consider what theological lessons emerge from these stories for both religious traditions and present this in the form of a chart.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: Examine a range of scholarly works to identify the terms of the Covenant of Abraham (Genesis) on God's part and on the part of the Israelites.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: Draw a map of Ancient Israel and locate and mark places of significance during the formative years of the Israelites.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: Research the background of a particular surah; complete biographies of key people related to this surah, identifying any connections between their lives and messages in the scripture.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: Identify and describe the historical people, places and events relating to the development of social attitudes and cultural beliefs as found in the Book of Ruth. Identify when and where the Book of Ruth was written, as opposed to when it is set. Describe a range of social attitudes, beliefs and teachings seen in the Book of Ruth.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: Convert selected texts into a play which has parts for the whole class. Act out the play and follow this with a class discussion that identifies the social attitudes, cultural beliefs and teachings in the selected texts.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: Research and outline the key teaching of a person who is regarded as a prophet by a religious tradition. Identify and describe their sociocultural and historical setting and their message.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: Choose an issue and an audience and write a prophecy, modelling this prophecy on Hebrew Scripture prophecies.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: Draw on particular passages of a sacred text and identify the intended audience of the text. Identify the issues the audience was facing at the time of writing and how these passages address those issues.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: The identity of the author of the Fourth Gospel remains a mystery; Christian tradition holds it to be the Apostle John. Drawing on the internal evidence from the Gospel itself, discuss what can be known about the author of the Fourth Gospel.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: The author of the Gospel according to John uses the term 'The Jews' to address a particular group of Jews within the society at the time. Discuss who these 'Jews' were and the conflict between them and the Johannine Jesus.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: Draw a map of the Arabian Peninsula and show the following locations: Makkah, Madinah, Badr and Hudaibiyyah. Annotate these to identify their significance for where texts took shape and developed.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: Write a report on the Jahiliyyah Period (Period of Ignorance) in Arabia. Highlight the religious, social and political conditions that existed in the region at the time and explain how these events influenced the way the Qur'an was revealed.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: Describe the circumstances that led to the Hijrah of the early Muslims to Abyssinia (Ethiopia) as well as the Hijrah of the Prophet from Makkah to Madinah.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: Research the rise and fall of the first three kings of Israel. Make a list of their failures and successes and the impact they had on the Israelite nation. Describe their legacy.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: Identify and explain each of the covenants made between God and the Israelite nation. Summarise the effect of each covenant on the Israelite nation.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: Draw a timeline of the major and minor prophets in the Hebrew Scriptures. For each major prophet, mark the kings in power at the time.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: Amos is renowned for his prophecy on social justice. Describe the political, economic, sociocultural and religious beliefs at the time of Amos's call. Outline the prophecies he made and whether his mission was a success. Provide examples from the Hebrew Scriptures.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Sacred texts in the past
ExampleText: Explain the concept of social justice in 8th Century BCE. List the social injustices that were present socially, religiously, economically and politically during that period.

Students go on to research the connections between the messages of the scripture and the lives of the Prophet and some of his close associates.

ExampleText: Outcome 2

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Sacred texts today
ExampleText: Understand the type of authority that a religious tradition currently attributes to its sacred texts, how these texts affect the current religious tradition's understanding of its relationship to society, and the effects of the sacred text upon society today.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Sacred texts today
ExampleText: Examples of learning activities

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Sacred texts today
ExampleText: Explain the belief of monotheism and its significance in different religious traditions.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Sacred texts today
ExampleText: Watch or read Martin Luther King Junior's 'I Have a Dream' speech; take notes on the key points about justice. Note the corresponding teaching of a selected religious tradition and links to the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights. As a class, discuss whether the points are still relevant today.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Sacred texts today
ExampleText: Collect a list of appropriate people from the present day or from within the last 100 years, who are calling or have called for society to change. The person must be using or have used a sacred text to inspire or guide their work. In groups, select one person from the list and research them and their work for an oral presentation.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Sacred texts today
ExampleText: Invite guest speakers from the Abrahamic traditions and following their talks, draw up a table comparing how Christianity, Islam and Judaism understand and use their respective sacred texts.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Sacred texts today
ExampleText: Canonicity refers to the normative or authoritative books inspired by God for inclusion in Holy Scripture. Outline five principles used by the Church for identifying the canonicity of a particular piece of writing.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Sacred texts today
ExampleText: Explain the biblical principle of sola scriptura and provide reasons for and against its veracity.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Sacred texts today
ExampleText: Use biblical texts, current Church teaching and the school's own vision and mission statements to prepare a booklet entitled 'The Dignity of the Human Person as found in Sacred Texts'.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Sacred texts today
ExampleText: Consider specific teaching from the Bible and social teaching of a selected Christian denomination and explain what the teaching says about social justice. Discuss how the work of an affiliated organisation uses the teachings to guide their work. For example, Anglicare and some of the Anglican Church's social justice statements.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Sacred texts today
ExampleText: Explain, according to Jewish belief, what the status of the words and teachings of the prophets are for the Jews of today, as opposed to the prophets' original audience.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Sacred texts today
ExampleText: Explain, according to Jewish teaching, whether there is any distinction of authority between the laws which are explicitly written in the Torah and those devised by the rabbis throughout the centuries.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Sacred texts today
ExampleText: Define authority and describe the different types of authority found within religious traditions. Identify any order of priority within these different types of authority. Draw an authority diagram to illustrate the levels of authority within a particular religious tradition. Identify the type of authority given to the sacred texts of a religious tradition and how this is demonstrated in the religious tradition.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Sacred texts today
ExampleText: Draw a concept map to represent the five pillars of Islam. In small groups, rank the pillars between 1 and 5 in order of importance for both the Makkah and Medina periods, giving reasons for the ranking. Each group then presents its results to the class.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Sacred texts today
ExampleText: Outline the Qur'an's ruling on Riba (Interest); for example, Surah 2:275-27. Discuss the views of scholars regarding the implementation of the ruling on Riba by Muslims today, particularly those living in the West.

ExampleText: Outcome 3

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Comparing religious traditions
ExampleText: Examples of learning activities

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Comparing religious traditions
ExampleText: Visit a not-for-profit organisation associated with a specific tradition and investigate how sacred texts have influenced the organisation's perception of its responsibility towards specific community groups in need.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Comparing religious traditions
ExampleText: Invite a range of guest speakers to comment on an issue concerning social equality from the point of view of their religious tradition. Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Interpreting texts
ExampleText: Construct a chart that provides the scaffolding for students to begin to recognise, understand and apply exegetical methods to selected excerpts from the passages for special study.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Interpreting texts
ExampleText: The chart contains three columns, the left-hand side comprising of a list of a variety of exegetical or critical methods, such as historical criticism, literary criticism, grammatical criticism, etc. Students can scan their passages for special study and find examples of excerpts where scholars have applied these criticisms to derive meaning. The middle column will be the example excerpt and the final column, the meaning of the verse through the lens of the said criticism.
